heading: Network Engineering Student | Interested in Network Security | looking for a PFE internship
post_content: I recently completed a 2 months internship at INEOS, my project focused on designing and deploying a Hybrid Security Operations Center (SOC),The goal was to integrate a virtualized lab on EVE-NG with a cloud infrastructure for monitoring and analysis. Over the two months, here's what I worked on:- Deployed a complete network topology in EVE-NG (Cisco routers, switches, FortiGate firewall, VLAN segmentation, OSPF routing, VPN setup).- Set up a local SOC with Dockerized services (Wazuh for SIEM, TheHive + Cortex for incident response, Elasticsearch and Kibana for log analysis, Grafana for monitoring).- Migrated the SOC setup to Microsoft Azure, configured a secure VPN tunnel with WireGuard for hybrid connectivity.- Built a centralized log collection pipeline using Wazuh agents, SuricataIDS, Filebeat, and rsyslog (check the attached images for the topology and workflow).- Integrated everything with Keycloak for single sign-on and access control.- Tested and validated the system for real-time monitoring, incident detection, and centralized dashboards.This was quite a lot for two months, but it really showed me how theory translates into actual projects, and how much more there is to learn when you get hands-on experience.I'd like to thank Dr.Ing ChaÃ¯maÃ¢ KISSI for her time , advice and invaluable help with writing and structuring my report , Mr MoussaÃ b Ouzid for the supervision and guidance throughout the project, IGADERN AYOUB for being a great fellow intern to share this experience with, and Rajae EL ABBADI and the HR team for making everything smoother on the administrative side .If you're working on something similar or just curious about SOCs, hybrid architectures, or any of these tools, I'd be happy to exchange ideas and hear your thoughts.#Networking #CyberSecurity #Security #PFA #SOC #Internship #Cloud #EVE-NG #Wazuh #Azure #Grafana #Keycloak #SIEM #Elk #VPN

heading: SOC Analyst
post_content: ğŸ” Building my First Honeypot ğŸ”I want to share my recent hands-on project in the field of cyber threat intelligence and attacker behavior analysis â€” a fully functional SSH Honeypot using Cowrie, securely deployed inside a Docker container.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» What I Did:-Set up Cowrie, a medium interaction honeypot designed to emulate an SSH server.-Configured it to accept any random username and password combinations, tricking attackers into believing they've gained legitimate access.-Deployed the honeypot in a Docker container to isolate it completely from my host system â€” ensuring that no real risk is introduced during active attack simulations.-Designed the environment to capture attacker commands, file uploads, and behavioral patterns in real-time for analysis.ğŸ“¸ Snapshot Insight:The left panel shows the attackerâ€™s machine attempting intrusion, while the right panel displays the honeypot logging and responding to the injected commands â€” silently recording every action.ğŸ¯ Why This Matters: Understanding how attackers operate post-compromise is crucial for strengthening real-world defense strategies. Honeypots give us an edge in threat hunting, SOC operations, and digital forensics.âš™ï¸ Tools & Tech Stack: Cowrie â€¢ Docker â€¢ Linux â€¢ SSH â€¢ Bash Scripting â€¢ Cybersecurity Analysis#CyberSecurity #Honeypot #Cowrie #Docker #EthicalHacking #ThreatIntelligence #BlueTeam #SOC #LinuxSecurity #CTF #Infosec #CyberDefense #DeceptionTech #MalwareAnalysis #CyberDojo

heading: Network Engineer | Farm Manager | Specializing in Network Infrastructure & Cybersecurity Solutions
post_content: Warning: becoming an ethical hacker may cause excessive caffeine consumption, spontaneous outbursts of 'Ah-ha!' moments, and a sudden urge to wear a hoodie and sunglasses indoors.To succeed in this field, you'll need:- A passion for puzzle-solving (and a tolerance for hair-pulling)- A knack for finding loopholes (and a love for exploiting them)- A healthy dose of paranoia (to assume everyone's out to get you)- A superpower-level attention span (to stay focused on lines of code)- A secret identity (to protect your loved ones from your newfound ninja skills)And don't even get me started on the required snacks:- A stash of energy drinks to fuel those all-nighters- A bag of popcorn to munch on during intense debugging sessions- A box of cookies to bribe your colleagues for help (just kidding... or am I?)So, if you're ready to join the ranks of the ethical hacking elite, buckle up, buttercup! It's gonna be a wild ride!
